item.title:
Super-human AI is nowhere near the top of the list of existential risks. In large part because it doesn't exist yet.
Until we have a basic design for even dog-level AI (let alone human level), discussing how to make it safe is premature. https://t.co/ClkZxfofV9

item.title:
Do ants ever sleep? Yes, they do, but not in the sense we understand sleep. On average, a single worker ant would take 250 naps each day, with each one lasting just over a minute. That equates to 4 hours and 48 minutes of sleep a day

item.title:
Endocannabinoids are powerful synaptic modulators, but there's so much we don't know about how they signal. Here we show that *postsynaptic synucleins* are required!
Shoutout @YueSunNeuro, @yulonglilab, @SudhofThomas, @BJunDing and the rest of the team!
https://t.co/i5Vpr2ucqN

item.title: @YueSunNeuro @yulonglilab @SudhofThomas @BJunDing eCBs are particularly cool in that they are retrograde messengers signaling from post- to presynaptic compartments. But little is known about how this postsynaptic signal occurs.
item.description: @YueSunNeuro @yulonglilab @SudhofThomas @BJunDing eCBs are particularly cool in that they are retrograde messengers signaling from post- to presynaptic compartments. But little is known about how this postsynaptic signal occurs.
item.content:encoded: @YueSunNeuro @yulonglilab @SudhofThomas @BJunDing eCBs are particularly cool in that they are retrograde messengers signaling from post- to presynaptic compartments. But little is known about how this postsynaptic signal occurs.

item.title: @YueSunNeuro @yulonglilab @SudhofThomas @BJunDing We started this project looking for potential synaptic phenotypes in mice lacking synucleins (Syn-tKO mice), and found virtually zero differences in basal synaptic transmission in the striatum of Syn-tKO mice. https://t.co/knfHkAULja
item.description: @YueSunNeuro @yulonglilab @SudhofThomas @BJunDing We started this project looking for potential synaptic phenotypes in mice lacking synucleins (Syn-tKO mice), and found virtually zero differences in basal synaptic transmission in the striatum of Syn-tKO mice. https://t.co/knfHkAULja
item.content:encoded: @YueSunNeuro @yulonglilab @SudhofThomas @BJunDing We started this project looking for potential synaptic phenotypes in mice lacking synucleins (Syn-tKO mice), and found virtually zero differences in basal synaptic transmission in the striatum of Syn-tKO mice. https://t.co/knfHkAULja

item.title: Things got fun when we tested plasticity. We found that Syn-tKO mice completely lacked corticostriatal long-term depression (LTD) and DSI - two forms of striatal plasticity known to depend on eCB signaling! https://t.co/MfcnE2rwgh
item.description: Things got fun when we tested plasticity. We found that Syn-tKO mice completely lacked corticostriatal long-term depression (LTD) and DSI - two forms of striatal plasticity known to depend on eCB signaling! https://t.co/MfcnE2rwgh
item.content:encoded: Things got fun when we tested plasticity. We found that Syn-tKO mice completely lacked corticostriatal long-term depression (LTD) and DSI - two forms of striatal plasticity known to depend on eCB signaling! https://t.co/MfcnE2rwgh

item.title: Is the eCB plasticity defect in Syn-tKO mice unique to striatal neurons? Strikingly, we also saw impaired eCB plasticity in hippocampus! So Syn-tKO mice have a broad defect in eCB plasticity, spanning multiple synapse types and brain regions. https://t.co/Uzj6tC2FMu
item.description: Is the eCB plasticity defect in Syn-tKO mice unique to striatal neurons? Strikingly, we also saw impaired eCB plasticity in hippocampus! So Syn-tKO mice have a broad defect in eCB plasticity, spanning multiple synapse types and brain regions. https://t.co/Uzj6tC2FMu
item.content:encoded: Is the eCB plasticity defect in Syn-tKO mice unique to striatal neurons? Strikingly, we also saw impaired eCB plasticity in hippocampus! So Syn-tKO mice have a broad defect in eCB plasticity, spanning multiple synapse types and brain regions. https://t.co/Uzj6tC2FMu

item.title: From here we wanted to chase down the mechanism underlying disrupted eCB signaling in Syn-tKO mice. Given synuclein's strong presynaptic localization, we first asked if presynaptic CB1R function was intact in Syn-tKO mice. To our great surprise, it was! https://t.co/zyrhdLSkdj
item.description: From here we wanted to chase down the mechanism underlying disrupted eCB signaling in Syn-tKO mice. Given synuclein's strong presynaptic localization, we first asked if presynaptic CB1R function was intact in Syn-tKO mice. To our great surprise, it was! https://t.co/zyrhdLSkdj
item.content:encoded: From here we wanted to chase down the mechanism underlying disrupted eCB signaling in Syn-tKO mice. Given synuclein's strong presynaptic localization, we first asked if presynaptic CB1R function was intact in Syn-tKO mice. To our great surprise, it was! https://t.co/zyrhdLSkdj

item.title: If CB1R function is intact, Syn-tKO mice likely have a postsynaptic defect in eCB synthesis or retrograde transport of eCBs. Through whole-cell recording and GRAB_eCB2.0 imaging experiments, we identified that eCB release is specifically lost Syn-tKO mice. https://t.co/vJyzBqAVJ2
item.description: If CB1R function is intact, Syn-tKO mice likely have a postsynaptic defect in eCB synthesis or retrograde transport of eCBs. Through whole-cell recording and GRAB_eCB2.0 imaging experiments, we identified that eCB release is specifically lost Syn-tKO mice. https://t.co/vJyzBqAVJ2
item.content:encoded: If CB1R function is intact, Syn-tKO mice likely have a postsynaptic defect in eCB synthesis or retrograde transport of eCBs. Through whole-cell recording and GRAB_eCB2.0 imaging experiments, we identified that eCB release is specifically lost Syn-tKO mice. https://t.co/vJyzBqAVJ2

item.title: To more directly test if synucleins function postsynaptically, we employed a viral rescue strategy where Syn-tKO mice were injected with AAVs encoding wild-type a-synuclein. Strikingly, postsynaptic rescue of a-Syn rescued eCB plasticity! https://t.co/algQmplnJi
item.description: To more directly test if synucleins function postsynaptically, we employed a viral rescue strategy where Syn-tKO mice were injected with AAVs encoding wild-type a-synuclein. Strikingly, postsynaptic rescue of a-Syn rescued eCB plasticity! https://t.co/algQmplnJi
item.content:encoded: To more directly test if synucleins function postsynaptically, we employed a viral rescue strategy where Syn-tKO mice were injected with AAVs encoding wild-type a-synuclein. Strikingly, postsynaptic rescue of a-Syn rescued eCB plasticity! https://t.co/algQmplnJi

item.title: To know *what* synucleins are doing, we performed a "plasticity screen": virally expressing mutants of a-Syn, we found that mutations in a-Syn's lipid-binding domains prevented rescue of eCB plasticity. Thus eCB signaling likely requires a membrane interaction event by a-Syn. https://t.co/6bg26aaYfi
item.description: To know *what* synucleins are doing, we performed a "plasticity screen": virally expressing mutants of a-Syn, we found that mutations in a-Syn's lipid-binding domains prevented rescue of eCB plasticity. Thus eCB signaling likely requires a membrane interaction event by a-Syn. https://t.co/6bg26aaYfi
item.content:encoded: To know *what* synucleins are doing, we performed a "plasticity screen": virally expressing mutants of a-Syn, we found that mutations in a-Syn's lipid-binding domains prevented rescue of eCB plasticity. Thus eCB signaling likely requires a membrane interaction event by a-Syn. https://t.co/6bg26aaYfi

item.title: Lastly, we know that a-Syn facilitates assembly of SNAREs, and since postsynaptic SNAREs exist (eg, LTP + AMPARs), we asked if postsynaptic SNAREs were also involved in eCB signaling. Indeed, viral disruption of VAMP2 impaired eCB release and plasticity. https://t.co/WlwFxCNzvi
item.description: Lastly, we know that a-Syn facilitates assembly of SNAREs, and since postsynaptic SNAREs exist (eg, LTP + AMPARs), we asked if postsynaptic SNAREs were also involved in eCB signaling. Indeed, viral disruption of VAMP2 impaired eCB release and plasticity. https://t.co/WlwFxCNzvi
item.content:encoded: Lastly, we know that a-Syn facilitates assembly of SNAREs, and since postsynaptic SNAREs exist (eg, LTP + AMPARs), we asked if postsynaptic SNAREs were also involved in eCB signaling. Indeed, viral disruption of VAMP2 impaired eCB release and plasticity. https://t.co/WlwFxCNzvi

item.title: Details in the paper, please take a look! So many questions... what exactly is this synuclein membrane-interaction event? Do synucleins engage FABP5? Extracellular vesicles? Glia are always in the mix somehow! Link between eCB signaling and Parkinson's disease?.. Much more to do!
item.description: Details in the paper, please take a look! So many questions... what exactly is this synuclein membrane-interaction event? Do synucleins engage FABP5? Extracellular vesicles? Glia are always in the mix somehow! Link between eCB signaling and Parkinson's disease?.. Much more to do!
item.content:encoded: Details in the paper, please take a look! So many questions... what exactly is this synuclein membrane-interaction event? Do synucleins engage FABP5? Extracellular vesicles? Glia are always in the mix somehow! Link between eCB signaling and Parkinson's disease?.. Much more to do!

item.title:
The number 121 is not a prime number, regardless of the number system or base we choose

item.title: @KordingLab I love the idea of this paper. And, I wonder about the final clause of the abstract, "otherwise unreachable insights into the workings of the brain." That seems like the kind of statement that is not possible to build compelling evidence for. Am I missing something?
item.description: @KordingLab I love the idea of this paper. And, I wonder about the final clause of the abstract, "otherwise unreachable insights into the workings of the brain." That seems like the kind of statement that is not possible to build compelling evidence for. Am I missing something?
item.content:encoded: @KordingLab I love the idea of this paper. And, I wonder about the final clause of the abstract, "otherwise unreachable insights into the workings of the brain." That seems like the kind of statement that is not possible to build compelling evidence for. Am I missing something?
